usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS CloudWatch occurs when attackers obtain valid AWS credentials (access keys, session tokens, or IAM user passwords) that allow them to read, modify, or delete monitoring data, dashboards, alarms, and logs.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Phishing or social engineering to harvest IAM user credentials.
    • Exploiting leaked keys in code repositories or configuration files.
    • Hijacking EC2 instance or Lambda role tokens via metadata API access.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized users can view sensitive log and metric data.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers can disable alarms, delete dashboards, or purge log groups.
  • Stealthy Persistence: Malicious actors hide their activities by modifying retention settings or suppressing notifications.
  • Compliance Violations: Tampering with audit trails and alerts can breach regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phished Access Key Abuse: An attacker tricks an engineer into revealing AWS keys, then calls CloudWatch’s DeleteAlarms and DeleteDashboards APIs to blind the operations team.
  2. Leaked Config Leak: A CI/CD pipeline inadvertently exposes CloudWatch IAM keys in a public commit; attackers use them to export VPC Flow Logs and exfiltrate network traffic data.
  3. Instance Metadata Exploit: Malware on an EC2 instance reads its attached role’s temporary credentials, then uses PutMetricData to inject falsified metrics and mask malicious activity.

threat.name: Excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Excessive IAM permissions occur when users, roles, or service accounts are granted more CloudWatch privileges than required—often via overly broad policies or wildcard actions—enabling unauthorized operations across monitoring, logging, and alerting functions.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and errant automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Assigning policies like cloudwatch:* or logs:* on * resources.
    • Wildcard principals ("Principal": "*") or overly permissive condition-less statements.
    • Service-linked roles with unchecked trust relationships.

Impacts

  • Data Tampering & Deletion: Attackers can delete log groups or metrics, erasing forensic evidence.
  • Alert Suppression: Overprivileged actors disable alarms or modify thresholds to hide incidents.
  • False Metrics Injection: Unauthorized use of PutMetricData can mask malicious activity or skew dashboards.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Unchecked changes to retention settings and alarms undermine audit trails and regulatory controls.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Log Erasure: A compromised automation role with logs:DeleteLogGroup permission removes critical application logs to cover tracks after a breach.
  2. Alarm Tampering: An insider granted cloudwatch:DisableAlarmActions silences high‑severity alerts during an unauthorized infrastructure change, delaying detection.
  3. Metric Pollution: An attacker uses PutMetricData on production namespaces to inject misleading metrics, causing ops teams to chase false positives.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: No encryption in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch traffic—such as agent‑to‑CloudWatch logs, metric submissions, or cross‑region stream replication—is sent without TLS, all data in flight is exposed to interception and manipulation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Network eavesdroppers, MITM attackers, malicious insiders
  • Vectors: Sniffing unencrypted HTTP calls from CloudWatch agents; intercepting non‑TLS API requests; exploiting misconfigured SDKs that disable SSL

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive logs and metric payloads (PII, credentials) can be harvested
  • Data Tampering: In‑flight modification of metrics or alarms skews monitoring and hides real issues
  • Compliance Breach: Transmitting regulated data unencrypted violates standards like PCI DSS or GDPR

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Agent Sniffing: An attacker on the same subnet captures unencrypted CloudWatch Logs HTTP requests, extracting application stack traces and secrets.
  2. MITM Metric Injection: A malicious gateway intercepts and alters CloudWatch metric submissions to suppress alerts about unauthorized activity.
  3. Replication Hijack: Cross‑region log replication over plaintext is hijacked, diverting logs to an attacker‑controlled endpoint for analysis.

threat.name: Public network exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Public network exposure occurs when CloudWatch endpoints (APIs, agent ports, or log ingestion interfaces) are reachable over the Internet without network restrictions, allowing any external actor to interact with your monitoring services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning for and calling the CloudWatch Logs or Metrics API from the public Internet.
    • Misconfigured security groups or VPC settings that leave agent ports (e.g., the CloudWatch Agent’s HTTP endpoint) open.
    • Exploiting default or missing endpoint access controls to push or pull data.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Ingestion: Attackers can inject falsified metrics or logs, corrupting dashboards and alerts.
  • Data Exfiltration: Public access to Logs APIs may let adversaries retrieve sensitive telemetry or application logs.
  • Cost Spikes: Malicious actors flood your CloudWatch with high-volume custom metrics or log entries, driving up usage fees.
  • Monitoring Disruption: Overloaded or tampered endpoints can degrade or disable your monitoring pipelines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Bogus Metric Flood: An attacker discovers your open CloudWatch PutMetricData endpoint and sends thousands of custom metrics per second, inflating costs and obscuring real alerts.
  2. Log Data Harvesting: Without VPC restrictions, a malicious user calls FilterLogEvents on critical log groups, extracting PII or credentials from application logs.
  3. Agent Endpoint Abuse: A misconfigured CloudWatch Agent on EC2 listens publicly; an attacker posts large log payloads to its HTTP listener, saturating instance CPU and network.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data exposure in CloudWatch occurs when logs, metrics, or dashboard widgets inadvertently contain PII, credentials, or proprietary information and are accessible to unauthorized parties due to misconfiguration or overly broad access.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain read access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Overly permissive CloudWatch Logs resource policies or IAM roles (logs:FilterLogEvents on *).
    • Debug or application logs that record sensitive fields (passwords, tokens, user data).
    • Uncontrolled export of logs to S3 buckets without proper bucket policies.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of customer PII, credentials, or proprietary business data.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI DSS.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and potential legal liability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Logs Policy Overexposure: A wildcard IAM policy grants all users logs:GetLogEvents on critical log groups; an attacker enumerates and downloads entries containing API keys.
  2. Debug Logging Leak: A misconfigured application writes full credit-card numbers to CloudWatch Logs; any user with log-read permissions can harvest them.
  3. Unprotected S3 Export: Automated CloudWatch Logs export to an S3 bucket lacks encryption and public‑access blocks, allowing anyone with the bucket URL to download sensitive audit trails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information

threat.name: Endpoint policy misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch endpoint policies are too permissive or mis‑scoped, unintended principals or networks can access or modify Logs, Metrics, or Alarms—effectively bypassing intended security boundaries.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised AWS accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • VPC Endpoint policies using "Principal": "*", granting universal access
    • Missing aws:sourceVpce conditions, allowing unauthorized VPC or on‑prem queries
    • Cross‑account Logs policies (logs:GetLogEvents, logs:PutLogEvents) without proper scoping

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Reading sensitive log data
  • Data Tampering: Injecting or overwriting metrics/logs
  • Boundary Bypass: Internal traffic routed without firewall inspection

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Principal Abuse: An attacker in another account uses a wildcard‑principal VPC endpoint to flood your log groups with bogus entries, masking genuine alerts.
  2. Cross‑Account Leak: A mis-scoped Logs policy lets an external AWS account pull your application’s error logs—including API keys—for reconnaissance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data at rest occurs when CloudWatch retains logs, metrics, or exported dashboards on disk or in S3 without encryption, leaving sensitive information exposed if storage is accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain storage access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Disabling or failing to configure CloudWatch Logs–encryption keys (KMS).
    • Exporting logs to S3 buckets without SSE or bucket‑level encryption.
    • Stealing EBS snapshots or backup files containing unencrypted metrics data.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: PII, credentials, or proprietary information in logs can be read directly.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of at‑rest encryption mandates (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA, PCI DSS).
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust if audit trails reveal sensitive customer or internal data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Export Leak: An audit log export to an S3 bucket lacks SSE‑KMS; an attacker with S3 read access downloads and harvests sensitive entries.
  2. Snapshot Theft: A malicious insider copies unencrypted EBS snapshots backing CloudWatch metrics storage, then mounts them elsewhere to inspect raw data.
  3. KMS Misconfiguration: CloudWatch Logs are left using the default AWS‑managed key instead of a restricted CMK; after an account breach, an attacker decrypts archived logs to glean secrets.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch fails to record administrative or data‑access events—such as IAM changes, alarm modifications, or log‑retrievals—there’s no trail of “who did what,” making detection and investigation of malicious or accidental actions impossible.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and automated malware.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Performing API calls (e.g. DeleteLogGroup, DisableAlarmActions) without corresponding CloudTrail or CloudWatch Logs entries.
    • Exploiting gaps in retention or delivery settings that drop audit events.
    • Leveraging direct SDK or CLI calls that bypass configured logging hooks.

Impacts

  • Delayed Detection: Unauthorized changes go unnoticed, extending dwell time.
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cannot be reconstructed, hindering root‑cause analysis.
  • Compliance Failures: Absence of required audit trails breaches standards like PCI DSS, HIPAA, or SOC 2.
  • Persistent Threats: Attackers maintain covert access and alter settings without fear of discovery.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealthy Log Deletion: An attacker with delete rights removes critical log groups; without audit logs, there’s no record of who or what triggered the deletion.
  2. Alarm Suppression: A malicious actor disables high‑severity alarms via the API; absent audit entries, on‑call teams remain unaware of the suppression and miss critical alerts.
  3. Configuration Tampering: A compromised automation script updates metric thresholds to hide malicious activity; without change‑logs, the tampering is indistinguishable from legitimate updates.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Non‑compliance monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Non‑compliance monitoring occurs when CloudWatch isn’t configured to track or alert on departures from security, operational, or regulatory policies—allowing violations (e.g., disabled encryption, open ports, expired certificates) to go undetected.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, and external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Failing to create CloudWatch Alarms for key compliance metrics (e.g., IAM policy changes, public S3 buckets).
    • Omitting EventBridge rules to capture CloudTrail non‑compliant events.
    • Not using Config rules or custom metrics for regulatory controls.

Impacts

  • Undetected Violations: Security misconfigurations and policy breaches persist unnoticed.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Failure to monitor compliance can lead to fines under standards like PCI DSS, HIPAA, or GDPR.
  • Increased Attack Surface: Misconfigurations (e.g., exposed databases) remain open until manually discovered.
  • Reputational Damage: Extended non‑compliance erodes customer and stakeholder trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unmonitored Public Bucket: An S3 bucket holding PII is made public; without a CloudWatch Alarm on the “PublicAccess” metric, the exposure isn’t detected for days.
  2. Expired TLS Certificate: A load balancer’s certificate expires; no metric or alarm is set for certificate age, causing encrypted traffic to fail without alert.
  3. IAM Policy Drift: An administrator grants AdministratorAccess to a user; absent an EventBridge rule to flag policy changes, the over‑privileged account is created without notification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isn’t available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

standard.ref: AU-5 Response to Audit Logging Process Failures
AU-6 Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting
AU-7 Audit Record Reduction and Report Generation
DE.AE-2: Detected events are analyzed to understand attack targets and methods

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggers—pieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

component.name: Amazon ECS Task
component.desc: Amazon ECS Task running within the Hub Account.

weakness.name: CWE-256
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-256: Plaintext Storage of a Password Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise. Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties, configuration file, or memory. Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource. In some contexts, even storage of a plaintext password in memory is considered a security risk if the password is not cleared immediately after it is used.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Apply the principle of least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
Every Amazon ECS task definition must reference two separate IAM roles, and each role must include only the actions and resources the task genuinely needs—nothing more, nothing wildcard:

  1. Task-execution role – used by the ECS agent to pull images, push logs, and decrypt secrets.
    • Allow only the standard operations (ecr:GetAuthorizationToken, ecr:BatchGetImage, logs:PutLogEvents, secretsmanager:GetSecretValue, and related kms:Decrypt) and scope each permission to the specific ECR repositories, log groups, secret ARNs, and KMS keys your service uses.
  2. Task (application) role – assumed by the containers at runtime.
    • List the exact AWS APIs the code calls (for example dynamodb:PutItem, sqs:SendMessage).
    • Restrict Resource to precise ARNs—one table, one queue, one bucket prefix—never *.
    • Add context conditions (aws:SourceVpc, aws:CalledVia = ecs-tasks.amazonaws.com, or service-specific keys like dynamodb:LeadingKeys) so the permission works only from the intended VPC and tenant partition.
  3. Guardrails
    • Attach an account-wide permission boundary that denies any role granting Action:"*" or Resource:"*" without conditions.
    • Fail CI/CD builds when a task definition references a role lacking the boundary or containing wildcards.
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer’s unused-permissions feature and prune actions not seen in CloudTrail for 90 days.
  4. Ongoing review
    • Rotate secrets and KMS keys quarterly; update role policies accordingly.
    • Re-run Access Analyzer and CloudTrail queries after every release to confirm that new features haven’t introduced broader API calls.

Applying strict, resource-scoped policies—backed by permission boundaries and context keys—ensures a compromised container can reach only the AWS resources it truly needs, dramatically reducing blast radius.

References

  • IAM roles for Amazon ECS tasks
  • AWS IAM best practices – grant least privilege

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enforce a secure container runtime environment
countermeasure.desc:
Every containerDefinition in an Amazon ECS task definition must run with the lowest possible privileges and a locked-down filesystem to prevent escape and lateral-movement risks:

  • Run as a non-root user – set user to an app-specific UID/GID; never rely on the default root user.
  • Read-only root filesystem – set readonlyRootFilesystem: true and mount only the few writable paths you need as tmpfs volumes (tmpfsOptions: { size: 64, mode: 1777 }).
  • Drop Linux capabilities – in linuxParameters.capabilities, list only what the process absolutely needs; otherwise use capDrop: ["ALL"].
  • Disable privilege escalation – add noNewPrivileges: true so the process can’t gain extra rights via setuid binaries.
  • Block host-level access – do not enable privileged: true, hostNetwork, hostIPC, or hostPID; avoid host-device mounts unless required.
  • Use the latest, minimal base image – prefer distroless or Alpine images; pin by digest to prevent supply-chain swaps.
  • Enable init process & seccomp where available – set initProcessEnabled: true to reap zombies; on Bottlerocket/EKS Anywhere nodes, apply a restrictive seccomp profile.
  • Validate in CI/CD – add a linter (Checkov, cfn-nag) that fails the build when a task definition:
    • runs as root,
    • has privileged: true, or
    • lacks readonlyRootFilesystem.
  • Continuous monitoring – enable Amazon Inspector container runtime monitoring (or Falco) on the cluster to alert on capability abuse, host-namespace access, or exec into a container.

A locked-down runtime slashes the blast radius if an attacker gains a foothold and aligns your workloads with modern container hardening standards.

References

  • Security best practices for Amazon ECS
  • Task definition parameters — readonlyRootFilesystem, noNewPrivileges, and capabilities

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation

countermeasure.name: Enforce image scanning and use trusted registries with image signing
countermeasure.desc:
Only deploy container images that are (a) scanned for vulnerabilities, (b) pulled from an approved registry, and (c) cryptographically signed. Build these safeguards into every ECS task definition and its CI/CD pipeline:

  1. Approved registries only
    • Push all production images to Amazon ECR (or an ECR pull-through cache that mirrors a specific external repo).
    • On the task-execution role, add an IAM policy condition that denies ecr:BatchGetImage when the repository tag Trusted ≠ true, blocking unknown registries.
  2. Automated vulnerability scanning
    • Enable ECR enhanced scanning / Amazon Inspector container scanning (--scan-on-push) for every repository.
    • Fail the build if the scan reports unresolved High or Critical CVEs.
    • Schedule nightly re-scans; pipe new findings to Security Hub or Jira for remediation tracking.
  3. Image signing & provenance
    • Turn on ECR image signing (AWS Signer or OCI Notary v2).
    • Attach an IAM permissions boundary that denies image pulls when ecr:ImageHasSignature is "false".
    • Reference images by digest (<repo>@sha256:…) in the task definition, not by mutable tags like :latest.
  4. CI/CD enforcement gates
    • Add a pipeline step that verifies:
      • the image resides in the allow-list registry,
      • the digest has a valid signature from your CI signing profile,
      • the latest scan report is clean.
    • Break the build if any check fails.
  5. Continuous compliance
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule that marks a task definition NON_COMPLIANT when the image URI contains an unapproved registry or lacks a digest.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer to ensure no cross-account ECR policies expose trusted repos to unknown principals.
  6. Key management & rotation
    • Store signing keys in KMS; rotate annually and update the Signer profile.
    • Keep an inventory of signed digests; retire any image whose base layer becomes EOL or high-risk.

References

  • Amazon ECR image scanning and vulnerability findings
  • Signing container images in Amazon ECR

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Implement robust image security practices
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every container image that reaches production is built from a minimal, trusted base, scanned for vulnerabilities, signed for provenance, and continuously re-evaluated before and after deployment.

  1. build from minimal sources
    • Start with a small, vendor-maintained base (Alpine, Distroless, Amazon Linux 2023).
    • Pin versions with SHA-256 digests to avoid unintentional upgrades.
  2. scan early and often
    • Enable Amazon ECR enhanced scanning / Amazon Inspector on-push; fail CI when High or Critical CVEs are present.
    • Schedule nightly re-scans of all production digests and open tickets for new findings.
  3. sign every image
    • Use ECR image signing (AWS Signer or Notary v2).
    • In the task-execution role, deny ecr:BatchGetImage if ecr:ImageHasSignature != "true"; reference images by digest, not mutable tags.
  4. restrict pull locations
    • Allow pulls only from approved ECR repositories (or pull-through caches).
    • Apply an IAM condition StringEquals: ecr:ResourceTag/Trusted = "true" to block unvetted registries.
  5. embed a software bill of materials (SBOM)
    • Generate an SPDX or CycloneDX SBOM during the build and store it as an ECR artifact or in CodeCommit for audit-ready transparency.
  6. continuous compliance
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule that marks task definitions NON_COMPLIANT when the image URI lacks a digest, signature, or trusted repo tag.
    • Review Inspector and SBOM output during quarterly security reviews; deprecate images that inherit EOL packages.

Following these steps guarantees that every ECS task runs code that is minimal, scanned, signed, and traceable, sharply reducing supply-chain risk and easing regulatory audits.

References

  • Amazon ECR image scanning and signing

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Integrate with dedicated secrets management services
countermeasure.desc:
Never hard-code API keys, database passwords, or tokens inside your container images or task definitions. Instead, keep them in a managed secrets service and let ECS inject them at runtime:

  1. Choose the right vault
    • AWS Secrets Manager for rotation-aware credentials (RDS, Redshift, third-party APIs).
    • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store (SecureString) for configuration values that don’t require automatic rotation.
  2. Create the secret
    • Secrets Manager:
      • aws secretsmanager create-secret \
         --name prod/rds/masterpassword \
         --secret-string '{"username":"app","password":"P@ssw0rd!"}'
    • Parameter Store:
      • aws ssm put-parameter \
         --name /prod/app/api_key \
         --type SecureString \
         --value abc123 --key-id alias/aws/ssm
  3. Grant least-privilege access
    • Add only secretsmanager:GetSecretValue or ssm:GetParameters to the task-execution role, scoped to the exact ARN of the secret or parameter.
    • If the secret is encrypted with a customer-managed KMS key, include kms:Decrypt limited to that key ARN.
  4. Wire secrets into the task definition
    1. "secrets": [
       {
         "name": "DB_PASSWORD",
         "valueFrom": "arn:aws:secretsmanager:us-east-1:123456789012:secret:prod/rds/masterpassword"
       },
       {
         "name": "API_KEY",
         "valueFrom": "arn:aws:ssm:us-east-1:123456789012:parameter/prod/app/api_key"
       }
      ]
    2. ECS passes each secret as an environment variable; it never lands on disk or in the ECS control plane.
  5. Rotate and audit
    • Enable Secrets Manager rotation (IDE or Lambda) or rotate SecureString values manually on a schedule.
    • CloudTrail logs every GetSecretValue and GetParameters call—send high-volume or unexpected access patterns to Security Hub.
  6. CI/CD guardrails
    • Lint Dockerfiles and repos with git secrets or truffleHog to stop new plaintext secrets from entering source control.
    • Fail the pipeline if the task definition includes plaintext environment values that match secret-like regexes.

References

  • Injecting sensitive data into containers using AWS Secrets Manager
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store – secure strings overview

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive IAM permissions for tasks
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, task definitions specify the IAM roles that tasks can assume. If these roles have excessive permissions, they create significant security risks. Attackers can exploit compromised tasks to perform unauthorized actions, such as accessing sensitive resources, modifying configurations, or escalating privileges within the AWS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Compromise tasks to abuse elevated permissions.
  • Misconfiguration: Assigning overly broad IAM policies to ECS tasks.
  • Insider Threats: Exploit tasks to access unauthorized AWS resources.
  • Application Vulnerabilities: Compromised containers inherit permissions and execute malicious actions.

Impacts:

  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers gain high-level access to AWS services.
  • Data Exfiltration: Unauthorized access to data stored in AWS services (e.g., S3, RDS).
  • Service Disruption: Tasks can modify, stop, or delete ECS resources.
  • Financial Impact: Compromised tasks initiate costly AWS services, leading to unexpected charges.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized data access may breach regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Privilege Misuse: An ECS task role is assigned AdministratorAccess, allowing an attacker to manipulate ECS clusters or other AWS resources.
  2. Data Breach: A task with S3 full access is exploited to read and exfiltrate confidential files.
  3. Service Modification: A compromised task with permissions to update ECS services is used to deploy malicious containers.
  4. AWS API Abuse: An exploited task with permission to access EC2 resources is used to launch instances for cryptomining.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Secret exposure in Task Definitions
threat.desc:
General Description:
AWS ECS task definitions may inadvertently contain sensitive information such as API keys, database credentials, or other secrets. If these secrets are exposed, attackers can gain unauthorized access to backend systems or services. This exposure can occur if sensitive values are hard-coded within environment variables, configuration files, or command-line arguments.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Access public or misconfigured ECS task definitions to extract secrets.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors gain access to ECS configurations.
  • Misconfiguration: Improper handling of environment variables or secret storage.
  • Inadequate Security Practices: Storing secrets directly in plain text within task definitions.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Attackers access sensitive data or credentials.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized users can interact with backend services.
  • Privilege Escalation: Exposed AWS credentials allow control over other services.
  • Financial Impact: Compromised secrets lead to misuse of cloud resources.
  • Compliance Violations: Unsecured credentials may breach data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Plain Text Secrets: An ECS task definition contains hard-coded database credentials, which are accessed through the AWS Management Console.
  2. Exposed Environment Variables: API keys specified in task environment variables are extracted and used to access external services.
  3. Misconfigured Task Definition: A YAML file containing AWS IAM credentials is mistakenly pushed to a public repository.
  4. Logging Disclosure: Debug logs accidentally print sensitive environment variables, which are accessible from CloudWatch.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.001 - Credentials In Files

threat.name: Unvalidated image provenance from untrusted registries
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, using container images from untrusted or unverified registries introduces the risk of deploying compromised or malicious images. Attackers can inject malware, backdoors, or vulnerable software into images hosted on public or third-party registries. Without proper validation, these images may be inadvertently deployed, leading to security breaches or system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Upload compromised or malicious images to public registries.
  • Insider Threats: Developers use unverified images due to convenience or lack of policy enforcement.
  • Supply Chain Attacks: Attackers compromise a legitimate image repository and inject malicious code.
  • Human Error: Operators accidentally pull and deploy untrusted images.

Impacts:

  • Malware Infection: Deployed containers run with malicious code, potentially performing data exfiltration or resource abuse.
  • Credential Theft: Backdoors within images steal IAM credentials or other sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious images may include scripts that degrade performance or sabotage operations.
  • Lateral Movement: Attackers use compromised containers to move within the AWS environment.
  • Reputation Damage: Using compromised public images can result in public scrutiny and loss of trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Compromised Public Image: An attacker uploads a popular image (e.g., a database container) with embedded malware to a public registry. An ECS task pulls and runs it without validation, leading to data leakage.
  2. Third-Party Repository Attack: An untrusted registry is compromised, and its images are replaced with trojanized versions, which are subsequently used in ECS tasks.
  3. Image Spoofing: Attackers create images with names similar to trusted sources, tricking developers into using malicious containers.
  4. Insecure Deployment Pipeline: A CI/CD pipeline lacks image signature verification, allowing untrusted images to be automatically deployed in production.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Use of vulnerable container image
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, deploying containers built from outdated or vulnerable images increases the risk of exploitation. These vulnerabilities can stem from unpatched base images, outdated dependencies, or insecure configurations. Attackers can exploit these weaknesses to gain unauthorized access, escalate privileges, or compromise application data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious Actors: Actively scan for containers running known vulnerable versions.
  • Insider Threats: Deploy images without proper security vetting.
  • Supply Chain Attacks: Compromised base images with embedded vulnerabilities.
  • Outdated Software: Using legacy images with unpatched security flaws.

Impacts:

  • Service Compromise: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities to gain access or control.
  • Data Exposure: Vulnerable applications may leak sensitive information.
  • Lateral Movement: Attackers pivot from compromised containers to other services.
  • Service Disruption: Exploited containers may crash or become unresponsive.
  • Financial Impact: Exploited containers can be used for resource abuse (e.g., cryptomining).

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Exploiting Known Vulnerabilities: An outdated web server image is exploited via a remote code execution vulnerability.
  2. Legacy Image Usage: A container based on an unsupported version of an operating system contains multiple unpatched CVEs.
  3. Embedded Malware: A compromised base image from a public registry contains a backdoor, allowing remote control.
  4. Vulnerable Library: An application image includes an outdated cryptographic library, leading to weak encryption and data leakage.

threat.name: Insecure container runtime and network configuration
threat.desc:
General Description:
In AWS ECS, insecure runtime configurations and poorly designed network settings can expose containers to unauthorized access, privilege escalation, and lateral movement within the cloud environment. Misconfigurations may include allowing privileged mode, exposing unnecessary ports, or using insecure communication channels.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers: Exploit exposed ports or insecure network configurations to gain access.
  • Insider Threats: Abuse privileged containers to perform unauthorized actions.
  • Misconfiguration: Incorrect ECS task definitions or security group settings.
  • Vulnerable Services: Insecure applications running in containers lead to exploits.

Impacts:

  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers gain root access to the host from a privileged container.
  • Data Breach: Sensitive data is accessed or exfiltrated via insecure network settings.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers manipulate or stop essential ECS tasks.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised containers are used to move within the ECS cluster or other AWS services.
  • Resource Hijacking: Unauthorized resource use, such as cryptomining.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Privileged Container Exploit: A container runs in privileged mode, allowing an attacker to break out and access the underlying ECS host.
  2. Open Ports: An ECS task is configured with public-facing ports, exposing internal APIs to the internet.
  3. Unencrypted Communication: Containers communicate over plain HTTP, allowing attackers to intercept or manipulate traffic.
  4. Weak Security Group Rules: Overly permissive rules allow inbound traffic from any IP, exposing containers to brute force or vulnerability scanning.

component.name: Amazon EventBridge Rule
component.desc: Amazon EventBridge Rule within the Hub Account.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to configure and invoke EventBridge targets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge targets, apply IAM policies that restrict which users and roles have permissions to configure and invoke targets. These policies ensure that only authorized entities can trigger actions on the EventBridge targets, preventing unauthorized operations and maintaining the integrity of the event-driven workflow.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the specific actions (e.g., PutRule, PutTargets, InvokeFunction) that need to be restricted and identify the users and roles that require these permissions.
  2. Create IAM Policies: Develop IAM policies that explicitly define which users and roles are allowed to configure and invoke EventBridge targets. Use least privilege principles to grant only the necessary permissions required for their roles.
  3. Attach Policies to Users and Roles: Attach the IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles in AWS IAM to enforce the defined access restrictions.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review IAM policies to ensure they are up-to-date with current organizational requirements and remove any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Monitor Access and Usage: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor who is configuring and invoking EventBridge targets. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or actions.

reference.name: Using identity-based policies (IAM policies) for Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging for all event activities in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility and security monitoring in AWS EventBridge, enable detailed logging for all event activities. Use Amazon CloudWatch Logs and AWS CloudTrail to capture and monitor event-related actions, including event publishing, rule evaluation, and target invocation. Detailed logging helps detect unauthorized access, misconfigurations, and anomalies, allowing timely incident response and improving overall security posture.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable CloudTrail for EventBridge: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled for your AWS account to log all EventBridge API calls. Configure CloudTrail to log both management events and data events for comprehensive coverage.
  2. Set Up CloudWatch Logs: Create log groups and set up CloudWatch Logs to capture and store logs generated by EventBridge activities. Ensure logs are retained for an appropriate period based on your organization's retention policy.
  3. Monitor Logs and Set Alerts: Use CloudWatch metrics and alarms to monitor EventBridge activity logs for any unauthorized or suspicious actions. Configure alerts to notify security teams of any anomalies or potential security incidents.
  4. Regularly Review Logs: Schedule regular reviews of CloudWatch Logs and CloudTrail logs to identify trends, detect potential threats, and ensure compliance with security policies.
  5. Audit Log Configurations: Periodically audit logging configurations to ensure that all EventBridge activities are being logged correctly and that logging mechanisms are operating as intended.

reference.name: Logging Amazon EventBridge API calls using AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in event payloads before sending to AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To protect sensitive data transmitted through AWS EventBridge, ensure that all sensitive information included in event payloads is encrypted before being sent. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encrypting data to safeguard against unauthorized access and potential data breaches. Encrypting sensitive data ensures its confidentiality and integrity, even if it is intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data: Determine which data fields in event payloads contain sensitive information that requires encryption, such as personally identifiable information (PII) or financial details.
  2. Use AWS KMS for Encryption: Utilize AWS KMS to encrypt sensitive data within the payloads. Integrate AWS KMS encryption into your application's event generation process to automatically encrypt sensitive data before sending it to EventBridge.
  3. Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure that encrypted payloads are transmitted over secure channels, such as HTTPS, to add another layer of protection during data transit.
  4. Regularly Review Encryption Policies: Periodically review and update encryption practices and KMS key policies to align with organizational security standards and compliance requirements.
  5. Audit Encrypted Payloads: Regularly audit event payloads to verify that sensitive data is properly encrypted and that no plaintext sensitive information is sent through EventBridge.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and validate event rule configurations in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain secure and efficient event routing in AWS EventBridge, regularly review and validate the configuration of event rules. Ensure that each rule routes events only to authorized targets and that the configurations are not overly permissive. This practice adheres to the principle of least privilege, minimizing the risk of unauthorized actions or data exposure.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Schedule Regular Rule Reviews: Establish a routine schedule for reviewing all EventBridge event rules to ensure they are properly configured and align with security policies.
  2. Validate Target Authorizations: Check that each event rule routes events only to authorized targets, and ensure that no unauthorized targets are included.
  3. Minimize Rule Permissions: Review rule conditions and filters to ensure they are specific and not overly broad or permissive. Adjust configurations to follow the principle of least privilege.
  4. Document and Track Changes: Maintain a log of all rule reviews and any changes made to event rule configurations for auditing purposes.
  5. Automate Validation Checks: Where possible, automate the validation of event rule configurations using AWS Config or custom scripts to identify any non-compliant or overly permissive rules.

reference.name: Creating a rule that runs on a schedule in Amazon EventBridge

PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to restrict access to the EventBridge event bus
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge event buses, implement resource-based policies that restrict access to only authorized AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users. By defining specific permissions within these policies, you can control who can publish or subscribe to events on the event bus, thereby preventing unauthorized access and ensuring that only trusted entities can interact with the event bus.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Authorized Entities: Determine which AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users require access to the event bus for publishing or subscribing to events.
  2. Create Resource-Based Policies: Develop resource-based policies that explicitly grant the necessary permissions (e.g., PutEvents, DescribeRule, ListTargets) to the identified entities. Specify conditions where appropriate to further refine access.
  3. Attach Policies to the Event Bus: Attach the resource-based policies directly to the event bus to enforce the defined access controls. Ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the resource-based policies to ensure they remain up-to-date with current access requirements and revoke any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Audit Access Logs: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor access to the event bus, ensuring compliance with the defined policies and detecting any unauthorized access attempts.

reference.name: Permissions for event buses in Amazon EventBridge

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation of EventBridge targets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized invocation of AWS EventBridge targets occurs when unauthorized users or services trigger actions or access resources through EventBridge, potentially leading to data exposure, service disruption, or unintended operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak permissions to invoke targets without authorization.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to invoke unauthorized actions on targets.
  • Misconfigured Policies: Overly permissive IAM policies allow unintended target invocations.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized actions could expose sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious or unintended invocations can disrupt normal operations.
  • Security Breaches: Compromised targets could be used to further penetrate the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Weak Permissions: An attacker exploits weak IAM policies to invoke a target and access sensitive data.
  2. Misuse of Privileges: An insider with elevated permissions invokes unauthorized actions, causing data leakage or disruption.
  3. Malicious Automation: Bots exploit misconfigurations to repeatedly invoke targets, leading to service degradation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in event payloads
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data in AWS EventBridge event payloads can be exposed if not properly protected, leading to unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intercept unprotected event data or exploit misconfigurations.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to view or extract sensitive data.
  • Misconfigured Rules: Send sensitive data to unauthorized targets.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection laws, leading to fines.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust due to data exposure.
  • Financial Loss: Costs from breach response and legal actions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Data: Attackers intercept unencrypted event payloads containing sensitive data.
  2. Misconfigured Rules: Sensitive data is sent to unauthorized recipients due to misconfigured rules.
  3. Insider Misuse: An employee accesses and misuses sensitive event data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1081 - Credentials in Files

threat.name: Unrestricted event bus access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unrestricted access to an AWS EventBridge event bus can allow unauthorized users or services to publish or subscribe to events. This can lead to unauthorized data exposure, manipulation of event data, or triggering of unintended actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit open access to publish malicious events or intercept sensitive data.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to the event bus to perform unauthorized operations.
  • Misconfigurations: Improperly configured access controls that allow broad or unrestricted access.

Impacts

  • Data Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive events or data.
  • Security Breach: Malicious events may trigger unauthorized actions or compromise system integrity.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended events could disrupt workflows or services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Event Publishing: An attacker publishes malicious events to an open event bus, triggering unauthorized actions.
  2. Data Interception: Insiders with unrestricted access subscribe to events and intercept sensitive data.
  3. Misconfigured Access Controls: Improperly configured access policies allow unintended users to publish or consume events from the event bus.

threat.name: Misconfigured event rules
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured event rules in AWS EventBridge can lead to unintended or unauthorized event routing, exposing sensitive data or triggering unintended actions. This increases the risk of data leaks and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit misconfigurations to redirect events to unauthorized targets.
  • Insiders: Incorrectly configure event rules, leading to unintended data exposure or actions.
  • Automated Bots: Detect and exploit weak configurations to manipulate event flow.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive data could be routed to unauthorized recipients.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended event triggers could disrupt services or workflows.
  • Security Breaches: Malicious actions could be triggered by misrouted events.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker exploits a misconfiguration to redirect events to a malicious endpoint.
  2. Incorrect Rule Configuration: An insider mistakenly configures a rule that sends sensitive data to an unauthorized service.
  3. Service Disruption: Misconfigured rules cause an unexpected series of actions, disrupting normal operations.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring for event activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A lack of logging and monitoring for event activities in AWS EventBridge can prevent the timely detection and response to unauthorized access, misconfigurations, or malicious actions. Without adequate visibility, security incidents may go unnoticed, increasing the risk of data breaches or operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Perform unauthorized activities without detection due to insufficient monitoring.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to EventBridge undetected because of a lack of logs.
  • Malware: Malicious software exploits system weaknesses without triggering alerts.

Impacts

  • Delayed Incident Response: Slow detection of unauthorized access or anomalies increases potential damage.
  • Data Breach: Undetected unauthorized access could lead to exposure of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Unnoticed malicious activities could disrupt services or workflows.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker accesses sensitive event data without being detected due to insufficient logging.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with access misuses EventBridge to send unauthorized events, undetected due to lack of monitoring.
  3. Unnoticed Anomalies: Suspicious patterns or unusual activity go unnoticed, allowing further malicious activities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

component.desc: Amazon S3 Bucket in the Hub Account.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption – All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption – Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.
