countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you define—regular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

reference.name: 2.1.3 - Ensure all data in Amazon S3 has been discovered, classified, and secured when necessary

countermeasure.name: Enable Amazon S3 server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesn’t record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

reference.name: 3.3 - Ensure AWS Config is enabled in all regions

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesn’t support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If you’ve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you won’t be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

reference.name: 1.14 - Ensure IAM users receive permissions only through groups

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Enable secure web access to WorkSpaces
countermeasure.desc:
To securely enable web access for users to connect to their AWS WorkSpaces via a browser, ensure that network encryption is in place. This involves the following steps:

  1. Enable HTTPS: Configure AWS WorkSpaces to use HTTPS for all web connections to ensure that data transmitted between the browser and WorkSpaces is encrypted.
  2. Install and Configure SSL/TLS Certificates: Obtain and install SSL/TLS certificates on your web access gateway to establish a secure connection.
  3. Use Secure Web Gateways: Implement secure web gateways that enforce encryption protocols and inspect web traffic for compliance with security policies.
  4. Update and Patch Browsers: Ensure that all users have updated browsers with the latest security patches to minimize vulnerabilities.
  5. Monitor and Audit Web Access: Regularly monitor and audit web access logs to detect and respond to any suspicious activities or potential security incidents.

By implementing this security control, you ensure that users can securely connect to their AWS WorkSpaces via a browser, with encrypted network communication safeguarding sensitive data against interception.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt WorkSpaces volumes with AWS KMS
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data at rest in AWS WorkSpaces, use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to encrypt the root and user volumes. This involves the following steps:

  1. Create or Use an Existing KMS Key: Set up a new KMS key or use an existing one in the AWS KMS console for encryption.
  2. Configure WorkSpaces for Encryption:
    • When launching new WorkSpaces, select the option to encrypt the root and user volumes.
    • Specify the KMS key to be used for encryption.
  3. Encrypt Existing WorkSpaces:
    • For existing WorkSpaces, recreate them with the encryption option enabled, using the selected KMS key.
  4. Manage KMS Keys: Regularly rotate and manage KMS keys to ensure the encryption keys remain secure and comply with organizational policies.
  5. Monitor Encryption Status: Use AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to monitor and verify the encryption status of WorkSpaces volumes, ensuring compliance with encryption policies.

By implementing this security control, you ensure that data at rest in AWS WorkSpaces is encrypted using AWS KMS, thereby safeguarding sensitive information against unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

countermeasure.name: Manage and disconnect idle WorkSpaces sessions
countermeasure.desc:
To reduce the risk associated with persistent idle sessions in AWS WorkSpaces, configure policies to automatically disconnect idle sessions after a specified period. This involves the following steps:

  1. Set Idle Timeout Policies:
    • Access the AWS WorkSpaces console and navigate to the settings for your WorkSpaces directory.
    • Configure the session timeout settings to define the maximum idle time allowed before a session is disconnected.
  2. Implement Group Policies:
    • Use Active Directory Group Policies to enforce idle session timeouts for users.
    • Define the idle timeout value according to your organization’s security requirements (e.g., 15 minutes, 30 minutes).
  3. Communicate Policies to Users:
    • Inform users about the idle session timeout policies and provide guidelines on saving their work frequently to avoid data loss.
  4. Monitor Session Activity:
    • Regularly monitor session activity using AWS CloudWatch to ensure that idle session policies are being enforced effectively.
  5. Review and Adjust Policies:
    • Periodically review and adjust the idle session timeout policies based on user feedback and security audit findings to ensure optimal balance between security and usability.

By implementing this security control, you ensure that idle AWS WorkSpaces sessions are automatically disconnected, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and enhancing overall security.

countermeasure.name: Restrict WorkSpaces access to trusted IP addresses
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS WorkSpaces, configure IP access control groups to restrict access only to trusted IP addresses. This involves the following steps:

  1. Create IP Access Control Groups: Define IP access control groups within the AWS WorkSpaces console.
  2. Specify Trusted IP Addresses: List the IP addresses or IP address ranges that are considered trusted and should be allowed access to the WorkSpaces.
  3. Assign Access Control Groups to WorkSpaces: Apply the configured IP access control groups to the appropriate WorkSpaces. This ensures that only devices from the specified trusted IP addresses can establish a connection.
  4. Regularly Review and Update: Periodically review and update the trusted IP addresses to adapt to any changes in network infrastructure or access requirements.

By implementing this security control, you ensure that access to AWS WorkSpaces is limited to known and trusted network locations, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches.

countermeasure.name: Use custom images for consistent WorkSpaces security
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure consistent security configurations and software across AWS WorkSpaces, create and use custom WorkSpaces images. This involves:

  1. Set Up a Baseline Workspace: Configure a WorkSpace with necessary security settings and software.
  2. Create a Custom Image: Use the AWS WorkSpaces console to create an image from the configured WorkSpace.
  3. Test the Image: Launch WorkSpaces with the custom image to ensure all settings are correct.
  4. Update Regularly: Keep the custom image updated with the latest security patches and software.
  5. Deploy Using Custom Images: Ensure all new WorkSpaces are launched from the custom image.

By using custom images, you ensure consistent security and software configurations for all AWS WorkSpaces.

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inconsistent security configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inconsistent security configurations in AWS WorkSpaces refer to the misalignment or lack of uniformity in security settings across the environment, leading to potential vulnerabilities and security gaps.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external hackers, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting configuration errors, leveraging weak security settings, bypassing improperly configured defenses

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Potential manipulation or corruption of data
  • Operational Disruption: Increased risk of security incidents affecting business operations
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from stakeholders due to perceived insecurity
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with security standards and regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured Firewalls: An attacker exploits a misconfigured firewall to gain unauthorized network access.
  2. Weak Access Controls: Inconsistent access control settings allow unauthorized users to access sensitive information.
  3. Unpatched Systems: A hacker targets unpatched systems that were missed due to inconsistent patch management.
  4. Improperly Set Permissions: An insider gains unauthorized access to data due to improperly set user permissions.

Implementing standardized security policies, regular audits, and automated configuration management tools can help mitigate these risks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted volumes
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data leakage through unencrypted volumes in AWS WorkSpaces involves unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on virtual desktops without encryption. This vulnerability can lead to data breaches during storage or transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external hackers, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting unencrypted storage volumes, MitM attacks, unauthorized access via compromised credentials, software vulnerabilities

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Potential data manipulation or corruption
  • Operational Disruption: Business operations can be disrupted
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from stakeholders
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider Threat: An employee copies unencrypted customer data and sells it on the dark web.
  2. External Attack: A hacker exploits a vulnerability to access unencrypted volumes and exfiltrate data.
  3. Misconfiguration Incident: An IT administrator disables encryption, leading to months of unencrypted data storage.
  4. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts unencrypted data during transfer between AWS WorkSpace and storage volume.

Implementing robust encryption, monitoring access controls, and regular audits can mitigate this risk.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized network access in AWS WorkSpaces involves illicit access to the network, leading to data breaches and malicious activities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Hackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors: Weak configurations, stolen credentials, unpatched vulnerabilities, social engineering

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Data manipulation or corruption
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with business operations
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stolen Credentials: Attacker accesses sensitive data using stolen credentials.
  2. Weak Configurations: Misconfigured network settings allow unauthorized access.
  3. Unpatched Vulnerabilities: Exploiting unpatched network vulnerabilities.
  4. Social Engineering: Tricking an employee to reveal access details.

Implementing strong authentication, regular patching, and employee training can mitigate these risks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1135 - Network Share Discovery

threat.name: Insecure web access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Insecure web access in AWS WorkSpaces refers to vulnerabilities that arise when web access is not properly secured. This can lead to unauthorized access, data interception, and potential exploitation of sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external hackers, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors: Phishing attacks, unsecured HTTP connections, outdated browser plugins, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data transmitted over the web
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Manipulation or corruption of data during web access
  • Operational Disruption: Disruption of business activities due to compromised web access
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from stakeholders due to perceived or actual web security weaknesses
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phishing Attack: An employee is tricked into providing login credentials through a phishing website, allowing attackers to access AWS WorkSpaces.
  2. Unsecured HTTP Connection: Sensitive information is intercepted by attackers during transmission due to the use of unsecured HTTP instead of HTTPS.
  3. Outdated Browser Plugins: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an outdated browser plugin to gain unauthorized access to AWS WorkSpaces.
  4. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and manipulates data between the user's browser and AWS WorkSpaces due to insecure web access.

Implementing secure web access practices, such as using HTTPS, updating browser plugins, and educating employees about phishing risks, can mitigate these threats.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Idle session vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Idle session vulnerabilities in AWS WorkSpaces arise when inactive sessions remain open and accessible, increasing the risk of unauthorized access and potential exploitation.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external hackers
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting unattended active sessions, session hijacking, leveraging idle sessions to gain unauthorized access

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Potential data manipulation or corruption
  • Operational Disruption: Unauthorized actions leading to business disruption
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from stakeholders due to security lapses
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unattended Session: An employee leaves their AWS WorkSpaces session open, allowing a malicious insider to access sensitive information.
  2. Session Hijacking: An attacker hijacks an idle session to gain unauthorized access to data and resources.
  3. Exploiting Idle Time: A hacker exploits the lack of automatic session timeouts to perform unauthorized activities during idle periods.
  4. Misuse of Credentials: An attacker gains access to an idle session using stolen credentials, leading to data theft.

Implementing automatic session timeouts, regular session monitoring, and user education can mitigate these vulnerabilities.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

  2. Install and Configure SSL/TLS Certificates: Obtain and install SSL/TLS certificates on your web access gateway to establish a secure connection.
  3. Use Secure Web Gateways: Implement secure web gateways that enforce encryption protocols and inspect web traffic for compliance with security policies.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data in transit between AWS Directory Service and clients
countermeasure.desc: Secure data transmitted between AWS Directory Service and client applications by implementing encryption protocols, such as TLS (Transport Layer Security). Configure AWS Directory Service to enforce encrypted communication, ensuring all data exchanges are securely transmitted to prevent interception by unauthorized parties. Regularly update encryption protocols and configurations to maintain strong security standards and protect sensitive directory data from exposure during transit. This control mitigates risks associated with data breaches and unauthorized access through network vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege access for directory resources
countermeasure.desc: To secure AWS Device Farm, implement the principle of least privilege by defining and enforcing clear access policies for directory resources. Ensure that users and services are granted only the permissions necessary to perform their specific tasks. Review and update access policies regularly to reflect changes in user roles and responsibilities, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access. Use IAM roles and policies to define granular permissions, and monitor access patterns to identify and remediate excessive permissions. This approach helps maintain a secure environment by restricting access to only what is essential.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Validate trust relationships with trusted domains only
countermeasure.desc: Ensure secure integration in AWS Device Farm by carefully configuring and validating all trust relationships. Establish trust only with verified and trusted domains to prevent unauthorized access and potential data breaches. Regularly review and assess trust configurations to identify and eliminate any connections to untrusted or compromised domains. Use tools and logs to monitor trust relationship activities and ensure that all trusted connections adhere to security policies and compliance requirements, thereby maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of directory services.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improper trust relationships
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper trust relationships in AWS Device Farm involve establishing directory trust with unverified or untrusted domains. This misconfiguration can lead to unauthorized access and potential compromise of sensitive data, as malicious domains might exploit these trusts to gain access to AWS resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious external domains, compromised trusted domains, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting improperly configured trust relationships, using compromised domains to access AWS directories.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive AWS resources and data.
  • Data breaches and potential data manipulation or loss.
  • Increased vulnerability to further attacks across interconnected domains.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A malicious domain exploits an improperly configured trust relationship to access sensitive directory data, bypassing security controls.
  2. An attacker gains control of a trusted domain and uses the established trust relationship to infiltrate the AWS environment, accessing or manipulating sensitive information.

threat.name: Misconfigured directory access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfigured directory access control in AWS Device Farm can lead to unauthorized access to directory resources. If access controls are not properly set up, users without appropriate permissions may gain access to sensitive directories, posing a significant security risk.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak or misconfigured access control policies, bypassing insufficiently restricted directory permissions.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Potential data breaches and loss of data integrity.
  • Compromised security of AWS Device Farm environments and associated services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a directory resource due to overly permissive access controls, allowing them to modify or exfiltrate sensitive data.
  2. A malicious insider exploits misconfigured directory access to gain unauthorized privileges, potentially disrupting services or accessing confidential information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unsecured directory data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unsecured directory data transmission in AWS Device Farm occurs when sensitive data exchanged between AWS Directory Service and client applications is not adequately protected. Without proper encryption, this data is vulnerable to interception, leading to potential exposure of confidential information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, network sniffers, malicious intermediaries.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted data during transmission, exploiting weak or absent encryption protocols.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive directory data, such as user credentials and configuration details.
  • Potential data breaches and unauthorized access.
  • Compromise of the confidentiality and integrity of transmitted data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses network sniffing tools to intercept unencrypted directory data, capturing sensitive information like usernames and passwords during transmission.
  2. A malicious actor exploits a lack of encryption in the communication channel to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, altering directory data or injecting malicious payloads.

weakness.name: CWE-1188
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1188: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

weakness.name: CWE-16
weakness.desc: CWE:

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-308 CWE-307
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required. CWE-307: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319 CWE-352
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-614 CWE-613
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-614: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.
CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-778 CWE-117
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.
CWE-117: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-79 CWE-20
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.
CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Automated configuration management tools
countermeasure.desc:
Automated configuration management tools help maintain system configurations in a desired, secure state. These tools can automate the setup, deployment, and maintenance of software across various environments, ensuring that configurations are consistent and aligned with security best practices. Here’s how to implement these tools for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Choose a Configuration Management Tool

  • Select a tool that suits your environment and needs. Popular options include Ansible, Chef, Puppet, and SaltStack. Consider factors such as ease of use, community support, and compatibility with your existing stack.

Step 2: Define Secure Configuration Baselines

  • Develop configuration baselines that comply with security best practices. This might include setting password policies, configuring role-based access controls, and disabling unnecessary services.
  • Utilize security benchmarks from organizations like the Center for Internet Security (CIS) as references for configuring security settings.

Step 3: Automate Configuration Scripts

  • Write scripts or 'playbooks' (in Ansible) to automate the deployment and configuration of the Account software component. Ensure these scripts enforce the security baselines.
  • Include tasks that check for default settings and change them, install necessary security updates, and configure firewalls or other security controls.

Step 4: Integrate Configuration Management in the Deployment Pipeline

  • Integrate your configuration management tool into your continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline. This ensures that every deployment is automatically configured to the defined security standards.
  • Use the tool to automatically apply configurations during both initial setup and subsequent deployments to maintain consistency.

Step 5: Regularly Update and Review Configuration Scripts

  • Regularly review and update your configuration scripts to adapt to new security threats and compliance requirements.
  • Use version control to manage changes in your configuration scripts. This provides an audit trail for changes and helps in troubleshooting.

Step 6: Monitor and Audit Configurations

  • Set up monitoring within your configuration management tool to track and report deviations from the defined configuration baselines.
  • Regularly audit your environment using the tool to ensure compliance with the security policies and to detect any unauthorized changes.

Step 7: Educate Your Team

  • Provide training and resources to your development and operations teams about the importance of security through consistent configurations and how to use the configuration management tool effectively.

Further Considerations:

  • Security as Code: Treat your security configurations and scripts as code. This approach aligns with the infrastructure as code (IaC) philosophy, promoting consistency and ease of management.
  • Documentation: Document your configuration management practices and keep this documentation updated. This helps new team members understand your security infrastructure and contributes to better security hygiene.

By following these steps and regularly updating your configurations in response to emerging threats, you can significantly enhance the security and consistency of your software environments.

countermeasure.name: Data handling best practices
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing data handling best practices helps safeguard sensitive information throughout its lifecycle to prevent unauthorized access, leaks, and data breaches. Here's how to apply these practices for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Identify and Classify Data

  • Inventory all data types handled, distinguishing personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, or other sensitive information.
  • Classify data based on sensitivity, such as public, internal, confidential, and highly confidential.

Step 2: Apply Data Encryption

  • At Rest: Encrypt sensitive data at rest using strong encryption algorithms like AES-256.
    • Use a dedicated encryption library or service (e.g., AWS KMS, HashiCorp Vault) to manage encryption keys securely.
  • In Transit: Enforce encryption for data in transit using TLS 1.2+ or equivalent for all network communication.

Step 3: Implement Access Controls

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Grant data access based on user roles, ensuring that only authorized individuals can view or modify sensitive information.
  • Principle of Least Privilege: Apply the minimum permissions required for each user or service account.
  • Separation of Duties: Divide access privileges among different roles to minimize insider threats.

Step 4: Secure Data Storage

  • Sanitize sensitive data before storage, stripping out unnecessary information.
  • Mask or anonymize data in non-production environments like development and testing.
  • Store data in secure locations and restrict direct access to storage systems.

Step 5: Logging and Monitoring

  • Log data access and modification activities for sensitive information.
  • Monitor logs for unusual access patterns or unauthorized attempts.

Step 6: Data Retention and Disposal

  • Define and enforce data retention policies to retain data only as long as needed.
  • Safely dispose of sensitive data by securely wiping files or physically destroying storage media.

Step 7: Regular Audits and Reviews

  • Periodically review data handling practices to ensure compliance with relevant regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).
  • Conduct security audits and penetration testing to detect vulnerabilities in data protection measures.

Step 8: Educate and Train Staff

  • Train developers, system administrators, and other staff members in data protection principles, including data minimization and secure coding practices.
  • Emphasize the importance of secure data handling throughout the development process.

Further Considerations:

  • Regulatory Compliance: Be aware of industry-specific data protection regulations and integrate those requirements into your data handling processes.
  • Backup and Recovery: Ensure that data backups are encrypted, securely stored, and tested for disaster recovery.

By following these best practices, you ensure that sensitive account data is properly handled and protected against internal and external threats.

countermeasure.name: Enforce anti-CSRF measures
countermeasure.desc:
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks trick authenticated users into performing unintended actions on a web application. Enforcing anti-CSRF measures ensures that your web application processes only legitimate, authorized requests. Here's how to implement these measures for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Use Synchronizer Tokens

  • Token Generation:
    • Generate a unique, unpredictable CSRF token for each user session or form. Libraries like csurf (Node.js), django.middleware.csrf (Django), or Spring Security CSRF (Java) can simplify this.
  • Token Insertion:
    • Embed the generated token in all forms that modify state (e.g., POST, PUT, DELETE requests).
    • For APIs, include tokens in custom headers rather than as URL parameters.
  • Token Verification:
    • Verify the CSRF token on the server for each incoming request. Reject requests missing a valid token.

Step 2: Use SameSite Cookies

  • Set the SameSite attribute for cookies to Strict or Lax to prevent cookies from being sent in cross-site requests.
    • Example for secure cookies:

Set-Cookie: sessionid=<session_id>; Secure; HttpOnly; SameSite=Strict
Step 3: Implement Referrer Header Checks

  • For sensitive actions, validate that the Referrer header matches the application's origin or domain.
  • Reject requests with an empty or mismatched Referrer header.

Step 4: Require Re-Authentication for Critical Actions

  • For critical actions like changing passwords or transferring funds, ask users to re-enter their credentials or use multi-factor authentication.

Step 5: Educate Users on Phishing Attacks

  • Provide security education to end-users, warning them about the risks of phishing emails and malicious links that could facilitate CSRF.

Step 6: Regularly Test CSRF Defenses

  • Conduct security testing, including manual tests and automated security tools, to validate that anti-CSRF measures are working effectively.

Further Considerations:

  • Framework-Specific Defenses: Leverage built-in CSRF protection if available in your web framework (e.g., Rails, ASP.NET MVC).
  • Whitelist IPs: Consider restricting sensitive actions to specific trusted IP addresses if feasible.

By following these steps and staying updated on new CSRF vulnerabilities, you can ensure your web application remains secure against these attacks.

standard.ref: Cross-Site Request Forgery Prevention Cheat Sheet
Insecure Direct Object Reference Prevention Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive encryption strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive encryption strategies protect sensitive data at rest and in transit using strong encryption algorithms. This helps prevent unauthorized access, ensuring data confidentiality and integrity throughout its lifecycle. Here's how to implement these strategies for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Classify and Identify Sensitive Data

  • Identify sensitive information, such as user credentials, personal identification numbers, and financial data, and classify it based on sensitivity (e.g., PII, confidential).

Step 2: Encrypt Data at Rest

  • Databases and Storage Systems:
    • Apply encryption for sensitive data stored in databases using strong algorithms like AES-256.
    • Use database encryption features, third-party tools, or file-level encryption.
  • File Storage:
    • Encrypt files containing sensitive information using standard encryption tools (e.g., OpenSSL, GPG).
    • Consider encrypting entire storage volumes (e.g., using BitLocker or LUKS).
  • Encryption Key Management:
    • Implement a secure encryption key management system. Use hardware security modules (HSMs) or dedicated key management services (e.g., AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault).
    • Rotate encryption keys regularly and ensure keys are stored securely, separate from encrypted data.

Step 3: Encrypt Data in Transit

  • Network Communication:
    • Use TLS 1.2+ for all communication between clients and servers. Obtain certificates from a trusted certificate authority.
    • Set up strict transport security policies (HSTS) to enforce secure connections.
  • API and Service Communication:
    • Apply mutual TLS (mTLS) for service-to-service communication to verify both parties' identities.
    • Avoid insecure protocols like FTP and HTTP.

Step 4: Encrypt Backups

  • Encrypt backup files, whether stored on-site or off-site, to ensure data remains protected in case of unauthorized access.
  • Follow the same encryption and key management standards as for primary storage.

Step 5: Secure Cryptographic Operations

  • Algorithms and Libraries:
    • Use industry-standard cryptographic algorithms and libraries (e.g., OpenSSL, BouncyCastle).
    • Avoid outdated algorithms like MD5 or SHA-1.
  • Configuration:
    • Ensure encryption parameters like salt, initialization vector (IV), and key sizes meet current best practices.

Step 6: Test Encryption Implementation

  • Regularly test the encryption implementation for proper configuration and possible vulnerabilities using security tools and penetration testing.

Step 7: Educate Teams on Encryption Usage

  • Train development teams to identify sensitive data and apply encryption practices.
  • Promote secure encryption usage in coding, key management, and protocol selection.

By following these comprehensive steps, you can ensure that sensitive data related to the "Account" software component is protected, reducing the risk of data breaches and unauthorized access.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive input validation and aanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive input validation and sanitization ensure that user input is processed securely to prevent injection attacks, buffer overflows, and other vulnerabilities. Here’s how to implement it for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Identify All Input Sources

  • Locate all input points, including form fields, query parameters, API endpoints, file uploads, and cookies.
  • Note internal sources like inter-service communication and system environment variables.

Step 2: Define Input Validation Rules

  • Establish validation rules for each input type:
    • Text Fields: Set length limits, restrict characters to allowed sets (e.g., letters, numbers), and disallow dangerous characters (e.g., <, >).
    • Numeric Fields: Verify the data type, minimum and maximum values.
    • Date/Time Fields: Ensure the date/time values are in the correct format and logical range.
    • Files: Limit the allowed file types, and check the file size.
    • Emails/URLs: Use regular expressions to enforce standard formatting.

Step 3: Implement Input Validation Logic

  • Use server-side validation for all inputs:
    • Apply programming language-specific libraries or frameworks for validation (e.g., express-validator for Node.js, validator.js).
    • Handle validation errors gracefully by returning informative error messages to the client.
  • For client-side validation:
    • Use built-in browser validation mechanisms or JavaScript frameworks for improved user experience.
    • Note that client-side validation should never replace server-side validation.

Step 4: Sanitize Inputs

  • Remove or encode potentially dangerous characters using appropriate libraries:
    • For text fields, escape special characters like < and >.
    • For file uploads, sanitize file names and paths to remove control characters or directory traversal attempts.
    • Use parameterized queries for SQL statements or prepared statements to prevent SQL injection.

Step 5: Secure API Endpoints

  • Ensure that APIs enforce input validation and sanitization as rigorously as web forms.
  • Reject malformed requests with detailed error messages while avoiding information leakage.

Step 6: Test and Monitor Input Validation Mechanisms

  • Perform regular security testing, including fuzz testing, to identify potential validation weaknesses.
  • Monitor logs and alerts for unusual activity that might indicate an attempted attack.

Step 7: Educate Development Teams

  • Train developers to recognize injection risks and apply secure coding practices in their daily work.

Further Considerations:

  • Security Frameworks: Leverage application security frameworks like OWASP’s ESAPI or web application firewall (WAF) rules for centralized input validation and sanitization.
  • Regular Updates: Keep all validation libraries updated to avoid relying on deprecated or vulnerable methods.

By enforcing these practices, you can prevent malicious inputs from compromising the integrity and security of the Account software component.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive logging and monitoring help identify security incidents, troubleshoot system issues, and track user behavior. Proper logging and monitoring help ensure visibility across the "Account" software component. Here’s how to implement these measures:

Step 1: Identify Critical Events to Log

  • Authentication: Log successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and session terminations.
  • Authorization: Record when users or services access sensitive data or perform privileged actions.
  • Configuration Changes: Track changes to user roles, permissions, application settings, or security policies.
  • Data Access and Modification: Monitor read, write, delete, or update operations on critical data.
  • Error Logs: Capture application errors and exceptions to identify potential vulnerabilities.

Step 2: Implement Centralized Logging

  • Logging Framework: Choose a reliable logging framework (e.g., log4j, Serilog, Winston) for your programming environment.
  • Log Format: Use consistent, structured formats like JSON or plain text with delimiters for log data.
  • Log Aggregation: Aggregate logs into a central repository using a solution like the ELK Stack, Splunk, or Fluentd to facilitate analysis.

Step 3: Protect Log Integrity and Confidentiality

  • Restrict access to logs, allowing only authorized personnel to view and modify them.
  • Encrypt sensitive log data, particularly when logs contain personal information or access credentials.
  • Enable immutability features or use tamper-evident storage for critical logs.

Step 4: Set Up Real-Time Monitoring and Alerts

  • Alert Criteria: Define criteria for suspicious activity (e.g., repeated failed logins, unauthorized data access) to trigger alerts.
  • Alerting Tools: Use Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems to automate monitoring and alerts.
  • Notifications: Send alerts to security teams via email, SMS, or ticketing systems.

Step 5: Implement Log Retention Policies

  • Retain logs for an appropriate period based on compliance, regulatory, and business requirements.
  • Archive older logs to cheaper storage or delete them securely after the retention period.

Step 6: Regularly Review Logs and Audit Security Policies

  • Analyze log data periodically to identify trends and potential weaknesses.
  • Conduct manual or automated audits to verify that logs are generated and retained per security policies.

Step 7: Train Staff in Log Management

  • Educate the development and security teams on how to manage, analyze, and interpret logs for improved incident response.

By following these steps, you can ensure comprehensive logging and monitoring practices that provide high visibility, enhance security, and help identify potential issues in the "Account" software component.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Computer Security Log Management

countermeasure.name: Implement content security policy (CSP)
countermeasure.desc:
A Content Security Policy (CSP) helps prevent cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks, clickjacking, and other code injection vulnerabilities by specifying allowed content sources for web pages. Here’s how to implement a CSP for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Define the CSP Policy

  • Self-Hosted Content: Only allow content loaded from your own domains and subdomains (self directive).
  • Third-Party Content: Restrict third-party content, such as scripts, images, and styles, by specifying trusted external sources.
  • Inline Scripts and Styles: Avoid inline scripts and styles wherever possible. If required, allow them using hashes or nonces.
  • Form Actions: Limit form submission URLs to trusted domains.
  • Other Resources: Explicitly control sources for frames, fonts, media, and objects.

Step 2: Write the CSP Header

  • Create a CSP policy using the appropriate directives:

Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'nonce-xyz'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; img-src 'self' data:

  • Common directives:
    • default-src: Fallback for other directives.
    • script-src: Sources for JavaScript.
    • style-src: Sources for CSS.
    • img-src: Sources for images.
    • font-src: Sources for fonts.
    • frame-ancestors: Limits embedding in iframes.
    • form-action: Limits form submission URLs.
  • Set report-uri or report-to to log violations without breaking the application.

Step 3: Apply the CSP Header

  • HTTP Headers: Send the Content-Security-Policy header in all HTTP responses, either through server configurations (Apache/Nginx) or web framework settings.
  • Meta Tags: As a fallback or complement, include <meta> tags in HTML <head> sections to apply the CSP policy.

Step 4: Test and Refine the Policy

  • Report-Only Mode: Initially use Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only to identify blocked content without enforcing restrictions.
  • Violation Reports: Review violation reports to refine the policy. Adjust directives until no false positives occur.
  • Enforcement Mode: Switch to Content-Security-Policy to enforce the CSP once the policy is stable.

Step 5: Regularly Monitor and Update CSP Policies

  • Monitor for CSP violations and new security vulnerabilities that might affect your web app.
  • Update the CSP policy regularly to keep up with changes in allowed content sources.

Best Practices:

  • Avoid 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' in production policies to minimize risk.
  • Consider nonces or hashes over 'unsafe-inline' to allow trusted inline scripts or styles securely.
  • Keep your CSP policy as strict as possible while still allowing necessary functionality.

By following these steps, you can implement a secure CSP that helps mitigate a wide range of attacks targeting your web content.
